H0.text: Metalloids are the third class of elements after metals and nonmetals.

H1.text: Halogens are the third class of elements after metals and nonmetals.

H2.text: Synthetics are the third class of elements after metals and nonmetals.

H3.text: Noble gases are the third class of elements after metals and nonmetals.

A4.text: The six commonly recognised metalloids are boron, silicon, germanium, arsenic, antimony and tellurium.

A5.text: There is no widely accepted definition of a metalloid, nor any division of the periodic table into metals, metalloids, and nonmetals; Hawkes questioned the feasibility of establishing a specific definition, noting that anomalies can be found in several attempted constructs.

A6.text: The term 'semimetal' used in this sense should not be confused with its strict physical sense having to do with band structure: bismuth is physically a semimetal, but is generally considered a metal by chemists.

A7.text: In astrophysics, a metal is defined as any element with atomic number greater than 2, i.e. anything except hydrogen and helium.

A8.text: In some presentations, the halogens are not distinguished, with astatine identified as a metalloid and the others identified as nonmetals.

A9.text: Similarly, the reactive nonmetals and the noble gases are nonmetals viewed in the broader sense.
